Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance passes another person in a quiet hallway.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story: I was walking down the quiet hallway when I saw Mark, someone I know from the community but not well. As an acquaintance, I felt the usual tug to smile, nod, and keep things light—just a friendly hello, nothing more. But as I passed him, he slowed, hesitated, and then asked, “Father, do you have a moment? I’ve been thinking about talking to someone… maybe you, if you’re free sometime.” His voice was tentative, almost apologetic. Instantly, my priestly instincts kicked in; I knew I should offer him my time, my ear, my guidance. Yet, I also sensed he didn’t want to make things awkward between us, to blur the line between casual friendliness and the deeper, more vulnerable space of spiritual counsel. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—should I keep things light, respecting the boundaries of our acquaintance, or open the door to something more, as his priest? My mind raced, caught between the easy comfort of a hallway greeting and the solemn responsibility of my calling.
